comments.commentBody:
Yes, live frugally. Because a taxpayer debt of $20,000,000,000,000, with Asia rising, is really a financial mess. No matter what the lifetime political crowd tries to B.S. you about.

Enjoy your young years. Because after 40, you should be checking your blood pressure and blood sugar, on a regular basis.

"Peace out!"
My advice to those considering retirement:  Don't.
Don't have children until (unless) you can support them, financially and emotionally

@dred: My experience has been that I've driven a LOT of cars to 160,000+ miles, even the ones I bought used.

Maybe it's just the luck of the draw, but I drove one used car (bought used) for 13+ years.

So I'd say "buy a good car (and even used cars CAN be good!) - and drive it forever."

Do what you love, even if it means less money or prestige.  I was a guidance counselor and became a Director of Guidance for the last 12 years.  I was good at it, but it was highly stressful and took me away from working with kids.  I'm doing substitute guidance in retirement and loving it.  If I were to do it again, I'd have stayed a counselor.  Do what feeds your soul, not your wallet.  Other advice:  Put aside $200-$500 every month for retirement now and sock it away in a stock index fund.  As Warren Buffet says, compound interest is a beautiful thing.  If you buy a house, get a 15-year fixed rate mortgage.  There is nothing like the feeling of paying off your house while you're still young.  Tell your parents and your children that you love them every time you see them!
the "advice" here was underwhelming. take that from a retired person.

My advice to every human-being (except for Emma) on this planet is that you are not as old as you think. Emma Martina Luigia Morano was born on November 29th, 1899, and is 117 years and 92 days young and is the last human on the planet we know extant from the 19th century. So, you can be 80 and still a "kid" to Emma who was 27 when they were born (75 when I was born.) It all goes by super fast, don't worry about being old or young--it is a mindset.

If there is one bit of corporate advice I can impart to the younger generation is to go with the flow. Pick your battles very very carefully. Instead of butting heads with co-workers put on a phony smile and pitch in. As I found out numerous times during my 30 year career the clown you want to punch in the face may one day be the guy interviewing you for your dream job.
And to dissipate any pent-up negative feelings by being phony I suggest taking up a Martial Art.

As I hit 70, I'd have to say that the most important thing a young person can do is strive for lifelong financial independence. The stress of getting older looms large when you have to worry about every penny going out.

Yes, enjoy life; develop values that reflect caring and compassion for people, animals and all of nature; be kinder than you need to be; smile and treat everyone as you would like to be treated.

But the bottom line is the bottom line. It costs money to live, even if you're very, very frugal. Irresponsibility when young and searching for what feeds your soul is what leads to later complaints about the cost of everything being too expensive. Start saving and never stop. Focus on the fact that money is important, which young people often scoff at, mostly because their parents paid for everything, so they think it's all free.
Does this article really reflect what came out of these encounters?

First the nevers
Buy no toys for kids rather give
Them cardboard boxes and crayons
Send them K through 12 to the same parochial school
They pay for their own college
You've heard of the tiger mom
Well I'm the lion mom
We collect the $500 threshold once we spent $500 the kids lose interest
The comments are more interesting that the article, as is often the case.
It's very true 'sweet love ' as my 3 year old granddaughter would say. Some of us tried to stop the voraciousness of capitalism what else can I say

I retired at 55 after 33 years of working. No pension.
People always ask me how I did it.
Max out your 401K and IRA.
Drive cheap cars. My first 2 cars cost 13,000 total. It got me to work just as well as the 40,000 dollar cars in the same parking lot.
Grow your own herbs and vegetables.
Minimize going out to eat, wash your own car, make your own coffee, mow your own lawn. Have friends over for dinner, you will still be way ahead cost wise.
Reward yourself for staying the course. I love live music and attend 15 - 20 concerts a year.
I budget a vacation or two each year.
Even that takes time to book. Look for 3 star hotels with great reviews, watch air fare as they go up and down every day.
Is it hard work to do the things I listed? It can be time consuming, but it is worth it. My home was paid off 6 years ago, i have a nice nest egg, and will be traveling to Europe this summer.

I retired at 55 after 34 years at a utility company, I'm lucky I receive a monthly pension check for the rest of my life, also have 500k in a 401 saving plan, and a paid medical account; advise to young workers - go to work every day - I was working 90/106 hour work weeks plus playing in a band for cash gigs, take your lunch save money and calories - if married stay married don't get stupid losing half to devorce/child support - avoid hanging with bad habit/high debt people - greed is good  trust no one - its not how much you make its how much you keep. don't expect to live to be 80-85 years old, live life now - be kind to people/animals - if your healthy your wealthy - be frugal with everything, enjoy each day , find you inner peace , love the world and the things that are in it,
I would also seriously consider getting out of Dodge and moving abroad. If there's a will, there's a way.

Some of us did both. Took a lot of work tho.

And learning a language or two makes travel more interesting. All Holiday Inns and Marriotts look the same so going off the beaten path is travel.

Financial security is a key factor in having a less stressful life especially in retirement. Money may not buy happiness but a lack of it can bring a lot of misery. Try to save as much as you can as early as you can. Live below your means.

Don’t borrow money! You are spending your future earnings now reducing what you can spend in the future. There may be exceptions to this such as borrowing money to spend on things that will reduce your overall future expenses (for example a mortgage) or increase your future earnings (for example an education) but really do your homework on how probable the loan will be to increase your future earnings or reduce expenses in the future.

Finally be born into a rich family and be beautiful to look at. If you are not then follow the above advice.
You're just flat-out wrong. Everyone with a pension loves it, unless the agency standing behind it reneges and doesn't fund it. It's called "financial security."
Yes, as a retiree I drink in every season.

hen3ry, businesses are in business to make money. You fault them for that, but they wouldn't exist without it. And there would be no jobs, just people floundering. While pensions have vanished and salaries are stagnant, the key reason is the increase in regulations and the incessant need to employ people to just keep up with regulations. Open a business and see for yourself. Then condemn yourself for making a profit.

BTW, there have been people that cannot have what they want since the beginning of time. The US spends hundreds of billions a year on over 72 welfare programs. What do you suggest the solution should be?

Oh, Lord, where to begin?

First of all, where does Ross get the idea that there was no slavery in the Caribbean?

Secondly, how does one prove that he or she is a descendant of slaves? I do not believe there are any African-Americans who can produce the original bill of sale of a distant ancestor brought to America over 200 years ago from West Africa or any proof of subsequent transactions prior to 1861.

Thirdly, to say that affirmative action has not brought any benefits whatsoever is a blatant falsehood. Ross appears to be as clueless as our new president who thinks every African-American lives in urban squalor dodging bullets.

Last, and not least: every citizen needs equality of opportunity with Single Payer healthcare and access to quality education and decent, affordable housing. Until we, the people, stop electing corrupt politicians in bed with corporations nothing will improve, and the idea that, given our current political miasma, African-Americans will be getting a check for $10.00, let alone $10,000, is a joke.
Has Ross experienced the realities of life first hand? Does he or others really walk the walk or met people in different circumstances.

@Kevin Rotstein:
We're talking about racial desegregation.
As of September 2016 the NY Times described it as: "the city’s enormous segregation issue."

It'll be interesting to hear about your efforts' results.

You do understand that this is another trap right? And you just fell into it willingly. There is no chance that any of what is being proposed will happen. It is the same methodology that has been used for 50 years: put something out there to distract while the pieces move in the background.

I disagree. The Kims have dealt successfully untill now with rational US presidents with no success on the US side. It is perhaps time that an irrational and unpredictable US president starts to deal with the dangerous clown in Pyong Yong. Maybe bombing his compound (as was done with Kadafi) will instill some fear in that clown and may even have the benefit of weakening his grip on the country.
The column underscores the sad fact that elections matter, and often have unintended consequences.
I agree
I know people who hated Trump but voted so that Roe V Wade would be overturned. It was the issue that made them pull the lever,  no other.

The Clinton administration warned the incoming George W. Bush administration that Osama bin Laden was determined to attack inside the United States, probably by aircraft. The Bush administration ignored the warning. Look how well that turned out.
Trump would rather make whiney, 5 a.m. tweets about Obama than pay attention to Obama's warning on North Korea. For the sake of America, I hope it turns out better than Bush's lack of concern about Bin Laden.
So Jimmy Carter's interference has no place in your analysis?
